awd_titl_txt: National Ecological Observatory Network: Operations Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
The biosphere is one of the planet's most complex systems with countless internal processes and interactions with the earth's physical processes and systems. It is imperative that we understand how the biosphere is responding to and affecting earth's physical systems, yet our understanding of the biosphere does not match our increasingly sophisticated understanding of the earth's physical and chemical systems at regional, continental, and global scales. The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is designed to understand and predict: (1) how ecosystems work and respond to changes, especially at large scales; (2) how ecosystem processes feed back to alter earth system processes, including climate and hydrology; and (3) the implications of these processes and feedbacks for human endeavors. NEON will enable research on the impacts of climate and land use change, unsustainable water use, and invasive species on the Nation's living ecosystems at the temporal and spatial scales that are relevant to human well-being. NEON will be the first research platform and the only national experimental facility specifically designed to enable research to answer continental-scale questions on causes of and responses to environmental change and the mechanisms involved in observed changes. NEON will be the first experimental facility to collect consistent and standardized biological measurements across nationwide sites and to make the data available in close to real-time. 

This award provides support for initial operations of the NEON observatory. Funds are provided to use the geographically distributed field and lab infrastructure networked via cybertechnology as an integrated research platform. Cutting-edge sensor networks, instrumentation, experimental infrastructure, cyberinfrastructure, support facilities including towers and board walks, and biological sampling plots will be employed in the continental US, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and Alaska. Airborne remote sensing systems and mobile laboratories will be deployed. Funds are provided for central technical, cyberinfrastructure, and project management facilities and support staff. Funds are provided for NEON's education and outreach portals and staff training programs. The data from these resources will be linked to computational, analytical, and modeling capabilities to create NEON's integrated infrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is a large research infrastructure operated by Battelle. In Operations, NEON gathers and provides long-term, standardized data on ecological responses of the biosphere to changes in land use and climate, and on feedback with the geosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere. NEON is a continental-scale research platform for understanding how and why our ecosystems are changing.  This award covers NEON Initial Operations, beginning May 2016.

Two complete Airborne Observation Platform (AOP) flight seasons were performed on this award.  The 2016 AOP flight season covered nine ecoclimatic domains with a single payload flown.  The 2017 AOP field season allowed the operation of two payloads and 18 domains to be flown. Additionally, full airborne data collection for the entire Observatory was completed with flights in Puerto Rico sites during 2018 and flights over the Hawaii site during 2019. 

At all 20 domains, field scientists maintained both aquatic and terrestrial instrumented systems and performed data collection in the aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems.  These activities captured the data that have allowed NEON to produce 181 separate data products that were made available to the scientific community on the NEON data portal, www.neonscience.org. Samples collected at NEON sites are also discoverable through this portal.  Some data are shared with other repositories (Ameriflux, Phenocam network) and aggregators (e.g., iDigBio, GBIF).

The NEON cyberinfrastructure was improved by the development of new data pipelines to process data from field sites and hardware to store and process the data.  Improved data pipeline software code increased raw throughput and the successful processing of data to nearly 95%.  Mobile data collection and sampling procedure applications were developed to electronically capture and transmit data in the field, replacing written data logs that required transcription.

The NEON Biorepository began operations during this award period.  Storage of NEON samples was centralized at Arizona State University (ASU) for archive and loans to interested researchers.  ASU developed a complementary data portal for searching NEON samples. The NEON Biorepository has received over 200,000 total samples to date.

The NEON Science Engagement and Education teams completed many activities, designed to inclusively reach the broader ecological and environmental science communities.  Data science tutorials were developed and made available on the NEON data portal and at workshops where NEON scientists taught others how to find and use NEON data in their research.  Training modules were also created for educational applications, including classroom teaching.  Data skills, training and other online educational materials are available to the public on the NEON portal. 

The NEON data and samples have advanced knowledge in disparate disciplines outside of the primary ecological focus.  These include epidemiology (e.g., tick and mosquito range expansions), metrology (e.g., development of new calibration methods for airborne turbulence measurements), pedology (e.g., broad scale soil comparisons), forestry (e.g., ecological constraints on complexity of forests), and earth system science (e.g., integration of airborne remote sensing and field campaigns).  Knowledge from NEON data and samples can be used to inform policy (e.g., forestry, water use, disease vector migration), among other applications.
